title: An interdisciplinary twin/sibling study of insomnia and links to behavioural and emotional difficulties
abstractText:
Between 9 -15 per cent of the adult population experiences insomnia symptoms with daytime consequences (Ohayon, 2002). This disorder is not only associated with higher health care utilisation and impaired quality of life, but it is also highly comorbid with psychiatric disorders including depression and anxiety.

This project aims to integrate research from different fields by obtaining information via postal questionnaires on symptoms of insomnia, associated emotional and behavioural problems, cognitive style and life events in a genetically sensitive sample of approximately 2000 young adults comprising sibling and twin pairs who are all part of the ongoing Genesis 12-19 (G1219) study.

Five specific research areas concerning the heritability of different types of sleep problems and associations with other difficulties and risk factors will initially be addressed. The project will examine:

  • genetic and environmental influences on different subtypes of insomnia;
  • genetic and environmental influences on insomnia in males and females separately;
  • concurrent and longitudinal links between insomnia and behavioural and emotional problems;
  • associations between insomnia and different cognitive styles; and
  • whether there are associations between genetic and environmental factors influencing insomnia.
